cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical wing structures of butterflies, including their distinct post-emergence physical states prior to functional flight.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: wings of a butterfly… initial post-emergence state of a butterfly’s wings

members.entity_description: The flight-enabling appendages of a butterfly that develop during metamorphosis and must expand and harden before enabling flight.
The initial post-emergence state of a butterfly’s wings, when they are soft and wrinkled before expansion and hardening.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physiological and behavioral processes that occur as a butterfly transitions from chrysalis to functional adult, culminating in flight.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: pumping fluid into wings to expand and harden… ready to take flight for the first time

members.entity_description: Process by which a butterfly circulates fluid into its wings to expand and harden them.
The initial act of flying that a butterfly performs after its wings develop.

cluster_classes.class_description: Biological processes and outcomes involved in a caterpillar’s transformation into an adult butterfly, including specific metamorphosis and broader developmental changes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Transformation of a caterpillar inside the chrysalis into an adult butterfly, described as astonishing transformations.

members.entity_description: Transformation process in which a caterpillar's body reorganizes inside the chrysalis and develops into an adult butterfly.
Adult form that the caterpillar develops into after completing metamorphosis.
Remarkable morphological and developmental changes occurring across butterfly life stages.

args.name: Adult Butterfly Organism
args.description: The adult butterfly as an organism, representing the outcome of metamorphosis rather than the developmental process itself.
args.justification: En_328200c3 is an organism outcome distinct from the developmental processes in 'Butterfly Development', so it should be modeled as its own organism class rather than mixed into a process class.
The entity 'butterfly' (En_328200c3) is the adult organism, not a process, so it fits better in the newly created organism class than in the 'Butterfly Development' process class.

args.new_description: Anatomical wing structures of butterflies, including their initial post-emergence physical states prior to functional flight.
args.justification: This class correctly covers anatomical wing structures and states; only a stable, shared Class_Group is needed to align it with related metamorphosis and emergence classes.

args.new_description: Physiological and behavioral processes as a butterfly transitions from chrysalis to functional adult, including wing expansion and first flight.
args.justification: This class focuses on specific emergence-stage processes within the butterfly life cycle and should share a Class_Group with other metamorphosis-related classes.

args.new_description: Biological processes involved in a caterpillar's transformation into an adult butterfly, including metamorphosis and broader morphological transformations, excluding the adult organism itself.
args.justification: After moving the adult organism entity out, this class should be clearly scoped to developmental processes and aligned via a shared Class_Group with related emergence and anatomical classes.

args.new_description: The adult butterfly as an organism, representing the endpoint of the metamorphosis process.
args.justification: The new organism class should be explicitly connected to the same life-cycle Class_Group as the related developmental and emergence process classes.

executed_decisions.justification: En_328200c3 is an organism outcome distinct from the developmental processes in 'Butterfly Development', so it should be modeled as its own organism class rather than mixed into a process class.
The entity 'butterfly' (En_328200c3) is the adult organism, not a process, so it fits better in the newly created organism class than in the 'Butterfly Development' process class.
